sections.title: Credit Recovery Strategies
sections.subtitle: Rebuilding your credit after financial abuse

sections.title: Understanding the Impact
sections.content: Financial abuse often leaves survivors with damaged credit, unauthorized debts, and a complicated financial history. The good news is that credit can be repaired, and there are legal protections available to help you recover.

sections.title: First Steps to Credit Recovery
steps: Get your free credit reports from all three bureaus (Equifax, Experian, TransUnion) at AnnualCreditReport.com
Review reports carefully for unauthorized accounts, fraudulent charges, or identity theft
Document everything - take screenshots, print reports, save all correspondence
File a police report if you discover identity theft or fraud
Place a fraud alert or credit freeze on your credit reports
Contact creditors to dispute unauthorized accounts or charges

points.title: Identity Theft Report
points.description: File a report with the FTC at IdentityTheft.gov. This creates an official record and provides a recovery plan.

points.title: Dispute Letters
points.description: Send certified letters to credit bureaus disputing fraudulent accounts. Include police reports and identity theft affidavits.

points.title: Creditor Contact
points.description: Contact creditors directly to close fraudulent accounts and request removal from your credit report.

points.title: Documentation
points.description: Keep copies of all correspondence, certified mail receipts, and responses from bureaus and creditors.

sections.title: Legal Protections
sections.content: The Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) provides protections for victims of identity theft and fraud. You have the right to dispute inaccurate information, and credit bureaus must investigate within 30 days. If abuse involved coercion or fraud, you may not be legally responsible for those debts.

sections.title: Consider Legal Help
sections.content: Many domestic violence organizations offer free legal assistance. An attorney can help you navigate debt responsibility, divorce proceedings, and credit disputes. Don't try to handle everything alone.

sections.title: Rebuilding Your Credit
steps: Open a secured credit card in your name only (requires a deposit, builds credit)
Become an authorized user on a trusted friend or family member's account
Pay all bills on time - set up automatic payments if possible
Keep credit utilization below 30% of available credit
Don't close old accounts (length of credit history matters)
Monitor your credit regularly using free tools like Credit Karma or Credit Sesame

sections.title: Timeline for Recovery
sections.content: Credit recovery takes time, but progress happens faster than you might think. Negative items can be disputed immediately. Most negative marks fall off after 7 years. With consistent positive behavior, you can see significant improvement in 12-24 months.
